Headline.Para: Happy Bipartisan Budget Blowout Day; Republicans pay dearly to get more money for the military.

LeadPara.Para: The U.S. House passed its giant spending bill on Thursday, fewer than 24 hours after leaders unveiled its 2,232 pages. This is no way to run a government. And as expected, the price Republicans are paying for restoring the military is a blowout for domestic accounts, which won't be remembered as the GOP's finest hour.

The $1.3 trillion bill is the last barge moving through Congress for a while, so Members loaded everything possible onto the legislation, from opioid funding to dollars for transportation. Some of the hoarier contents will be discovered in the days to come, though not before both chambers whoop the thing through. The House passed the measure 256-167, and the Senate will follow before leaving town at the end of the week. Congress is spending enough to keep nearly everyone but taxpayers happy.

TailParas.Para: The GOP deserves credit for increasing funding for a U.S. military that is in worse shape than is commonly understood. Years of sequestration cuts and unreliable budgets have corroded equipment, training and proficiency. All of this ripples into retention problems and perhaps even death, as too many fatal training accidents continue.

A Navy F/A-18 was upside down in shallow water off Key West last week after crashing on approach to a naval air station. Both aviators died. The Pentagon declined to draw a direct connection but reiterated the need for stable appropriations, which can fund better equipment and more flying hours for pilots. Thus the GOP's $61 billion increase over 2017 levels, the largest bump in 15 years, is more of a backfill than a Reagan-style buildup.

But the Obama Administration's military starvation—including cramping pay increases that the deal funds at 2.4%—continues to pay off for the left, which could extort the Defense weaknesses for more money elsewhere. And Democrats got their loot, including $21 billion on infrastructure.

President Trump won more than $1.5 billion for "physical barriers" and supplies on the U.S. border—but please don't spook Democrats by calling it a wall. Both parties are taking credit for roughly $4 billion on opioids that may or may not help alleviate that social crisis.

Mr. Trump threatened to veto the bill over funding for the Gateway project under the Hudson River in New York and New Jersey. The tunnel is sorely needed and would help the entire Northeast region, but New York and New Jersey aren't contributing enough and the costs will balloon thanks to union work rules and pay demands. The bill removed a provision essentially steering money directly to Gateway, though the project may eventually finagle some of the funding.

A good development is that the bill includes a technical correction on the tax law's "grain glitch" that could allow some farmers to zero out their taxable income, which is an embarrassing Republican drafting error. The significant downside: Democrats demanded an expansion of the low-income housing tax credit as the price. Next time the GOP should hire a copy editor.

The legislation also includes better reporting requirements on background checks for gun purchases. This strengthens existing standards and allows the GOP to accomplish a compromise on guns without a hostage exercise from a Democratic Party that wants a ban on some rifles.

A cash pile for ObamaCare fell apart after Democrats balked over routine stipulations that taxpayer dollars cannot subsidize abortion. Kristi Noem of South Dakota tried to add an online sales tax. Leadership rejected this bad idea that might have derailed the spending bill, but it will return.

One conclusion is that the GOP has paid dearly for surrendering the normal appropriations process that allows horse-trading in committee with rank-and file Democrats over improvements on policy. The catch-all omnibus instead subjects every last provision to the red pen of Nancy Pelosi, Chuck Schumer and the interest groups they answer to. This scuttled GOP priorities like fixing the "joint-employer" labor standard that threatens franchising as a business model.

The shame is that this might be the last hurrah for the 115th Congress. The GOP Senate doesn't want to risk a tough vote to pass a budget resolution this year, so Democrats can subject everything to a 60-vote filibuster. The military had better spend this money wisely because Speaker Pelosi will have other plans.
